title: How does the length of daytime and nighttime affect the season? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think you might want to rethink how you’ve formulated your question. That said, I’m going to give it a shot anyway. If I was to answer your question directly, I would say that a day in a season - say, summer - is affected by a lengthier daytime (the amount of daytime hours in the summer relative to your distance from the equator) by making it warmer… but that’s not exactly true. Summers are warmer than winters because the Earth’s axis is on a tilt. That said, we’d get less of that warmth if we had less daytime hours, right? On the subject of Seasonal Affective Disorder, and with a little creative interpretation of your question - the presence of sunlight increases your brain’s production of serotonin, a chemical and neurotransmitter in the human body produced in the brain, bowels, and blood platelets. Low levels of serotonin, also known as “the happy chemical”, have been linked to depression. Depression occurring in annual waves, directly related to seasonal changes (and often measurable through the summer and winter solstices) is the primary characteristic of Seasonal Affective Disorder. Therefore the length of daytime your body receives can be linked to your serotonin levels and (if low) your depression. Disclaimer: I am in no way shape or form a doctor or practitioner of medicine. I am, however, a chronic sufferer of Seasonal Affective Disorder.
